awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Rethinking Access Pattern Privacy: From Theory to Practice
awd_abstract_narration:
When a program accesses data stored in memory, disk, or on a remote server, its access patterns can leak information about its secret inputs and data. There has been decades of work that investigated how to prevent programs from leaking any information by making their access patterns "oblivious", i.e., independent from their execution. This project is motivated by the significant overhead that past techniques incur. The project introduces and investigates new relaxed notions of access pattern obliviousness, and discovers new algorithms that achieve these notions with a significantly reduced overhead. The project includes training of Ph.D. students and postdoctoral researchers, and mentoring activities focused on high school, undergraduate, and graduate students.
 
This project rethinks the definition of access pattern privacy, and considers (but not limited to) a new notion called "differential obliviousness". In analogy with differential privacy, differential obliviosness requires that the access patterns resulting from executing a program on similar inputs should be hard to distinguish. The project establishes theoretical understanding, including new lower and upper bounds, of the extent to which various notions of obliviosness impact the performance of programs. The investigators also explore the practical performance of new privacy-preserving algorithms in cloud outsourcing and database scenarios. The project develops open-source libraries for the new, differentially oblivious algorithms and data structures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Oblivious RAM is an algorithmic technique for obfuscating access patterns to date. Although ORAM has been deployed at a large scale in prominent real-world applications, in many scenarios, there are some fundamental performance barriers if one insists on achieving full obliviousness. In this project, we explored a relaxed notion of access pattern privacy called Differential Obliviousness (DO). Essentially, DO applies the notion of differential privacy to access patterns. With DO, the hope is to overcome the performance barriers of full obliviousness while retaining the ability to mathematically quantify privacy. We showed that indeed, in many application scenarios, DO algorithms outperform fully oblivious algorithms not just asymptotically, but also concretely. Specifically, we designed and built a differentially oblivious relational database called Adore which demonstrated the advantage of DO algorithms over fully oblivious algorithms in realistic settings. 

We also developed a theory of composition for DO. It turns out that DO composition is more subtle than the composition of standard differential privacy (DP). Specifically, in DO, we care about the case when the output of the first DO algorithm is fed as input to the second DO algorithm, and the composition is trickier than DP because the standard notion of DO does not guarantee that two neighboring inputs would produce neighboring outputs. We proposed a refinement of the DO notion called Neighbor-Preserving DO (NPDO) which seems sufficiently general for capturing a wide class of known DO algorithms, and we prove a composition theorem for NPDO. Just like how composition theorems are of foundational importance in the applications of differential privacy, our DO composition theorems will also serve as a cornerstone in the design of DO algorithms. 

In the proposed work, we trained several graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who now hold tenure-track positions in academic institutions or research scientist positions in industry. We also developed new lecture notes on “Crypto Meets Algorithms”, with an emphasis on techniques for achieving access pattern privacy efficiently.


Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Elaine Shi
